questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 10 weeks' gestation because of progressive fatigue for the past 3 weeks. She reports that she has had a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss after conceiving despite an increase in appetite. She has become increasingly anxious and has trouble falling asleep. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (120 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. The globes of the eyes are prominent. The thyroid gland is firm and diffusely enlarged. Neurologic examination shows a fine resting tremor of the hands. There is a midsystolic click at the apex and a grade 2/6 early systolic murmur at the upper left sternal border. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration is 0.1 μU/mL. An ECG is normal except for sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lugol's iodine can cause a transient reduction in the levels of thyroid hormones (due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect), but after 5–10 days serum iodine would increase the production of T3 and T4 and thus exacerbate the patient's hyperthyroidism. In patients with Graves disease, the Wolff-Chaikoff effect of iodine can be utilized 5–10 days before thyroidectomy to prevent a thyroid storm. However, thyroidectomy is contraindicated during the first trimester because of teratogenicity associated with anesthetic drugs and the increased risk of fetal loss after major surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroidectomy can be used to treat Graves disease. However, thyroidectomy is contraindicated during the first and third trimesters because of teratogenicity associated with anesthetic drugs, increased risk of fetal loss during the first trimester, and the increased risk of preterm labor during the third trimester. If thyroidectomy is indicated, it should be performed during the second half of the second trimester.

C) CORRECT:

For a pregnant woman with Graves disease, propylthiouracil (PTU) is the therapy of choice during the first trimester. PTU crosses the placenta less readily and is associated with a lower risk of birth defects when compared with methimazole. During therapy, T3 and T4 levels should be checked every 3 weeks and the dose of PTU should be decreased once the mother is euthyroid or only mildly hyperthyroid so that fetal hypothyroidism does not occur. Methimazole is the preferred antithyroid drug during the second and third trimesters as PTU is associated with a higher risk of hepatocellular damage and agranulocytosis when compared with methimazole.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is the antithyroid drug of choice during the second and third trimesters. However, it is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is teratogenic and associated with congenital defects such as aplasia cutis, choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, and omphalocele (methimazole embryopathy).

E) INCORRECT:

The use of radioiodine (either diagnostic or therapeutic) is contraindicated during pregnancy because radioiodine can destroy the fetal thyroid gland and cause congenital hypothyroidism.

F) INCORRECT:

In pregnant women with Graves disease, observation without therapy would be appropriate during the first trimester if the patient was treated prior to becoming pregnant and has a stable euthyroid state with falling TSH receptor antibody (TRAb) levels. In pregnant women with untreated Graves disease, IgG TRAbs cross the placenta and stimulate the fetal thyroid, causing fetal thyromegaly and fetal thyrotoxicosis, which are associated with preterm delivery and high neonatal mortality of 10–20% (due to heart failure, tracheal compression caused by a goiter, infections, and/or thrombocytopenia). Untreated maternal hyperthyroidism is also associated with increased maternal mortality (due to pre-eclampsia, maternal heart failure, placental abruption, and/or thyroid storm).

G) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers such as propranolol and metoprolol are safe during pregnancy and can therefore be used as a part of initial therapy to reduce heart rate and treat symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (e.g., anxiety, palpitations, sweating) until the patient becomes euthyroid. However, atenolol is associated with an increased risk of fetal growth restriction; its use during pregnancy is therefore contraindicated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features suggestive of Graves disease: hyperthyroidism (weight loss, fatigue, anxiety, insomnia, tachycardia, systolic murmur, ↓ TSH), Graves ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos), and a diffusely enlarged goiter.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, malaise, and fatigue. Last night, she had a temperature of 40.8°C (104.2°F). She has also had difficulty swallowing since this morning. The patient was recently diagnosed with Graves disease and started on methimazole. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 134/74 mm Hg. The oropharynx is erythematous without exudate. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
42%


Hemoglobin
13.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
3200/mm3


 Segmented neutrophils

9%


 Basophils
< 1%


 Eosinophils
< 1%


 Lymphocytes
79%


 Monocytes
11%


Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Test for EBV, HIV, and CMV

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with agranulocytosis, bone marrow biopsy is useful for determining bone marrow disorders and malignancies as the underlying cause. Because bone marrow disorders (e.g., aplastic anemia) typically affect all cell lines, it is unlikely in this patient. The majority of cases of agranulocytosis are of a different etiology that can be determined without performing invasive tests.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has recently started taking methimazole, an antithyroid drug that is associated with a high risk of drug-induced neutropenia, which usually occurs within the first 3 months of treatment. In patients with laboratory evidence of agranulocytosis and signs of active infection, the most appropriate next step in management is to immediately discontinue the offending drug, even if the patient is symptomatic. Blood cultures should also be taken and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotic treatment initiated. Depending on the severity of neutropenia, administration of G-CSF may be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil, like other drugs in the thionamide class, can cause agranulocytosis. However, if a patient develops agranulocytosis while taking a thionamide drug, the use of another drug of the same class is contraindicated because of the high risk of crossreactivity.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral infection with EBV, HIV, or CMV could explain this patient's fever, malaise, dysphagia, and erythematous pharynx. Furthermore, infection with these viruses can suppress hematopoiesis, resulting in pancytopenia. Agranulocytosis, however, would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is most probably causing this patient's agranulocytosis. However, decreasing the dose of methimazole in a patient presenting with drug-induced agranulocytosis and signs of active infection is not sufficient. In patients with laboratory evidence of drug-induced neutropenia, the offending drug should be discontinued entirely.

F) INCORRECT:

Administration of oral aminopenicillin is the treatment of choice for patients with acute GAS tonsillitis. While this patient's findings (fever, malaise, dysphagia) are suggestive of acute tonsillitis, the absence of tonsillar exudate makes it unlikely. More importantly, this patient's laboratory tests confirm that she has agranulocytosis. She is at high risk of developing a severe, systemic infection. Oral antibiotics would not be sufficient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of active infection (fever, chills, malaise) and the laboratory tests confirm agranulocytosis. This should be considered a medical emergency and requires immediate management of the underlying cause.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician with fever and malaise. For the past two days, she has felt fatigued and weak and has had chills. Last night, she had a temperature of 40.8°C (104.2°F). She has had a sore throat since this morning. The patient was recently diagnosed with Graves disease and started on methimazole. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
3,200/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils

8%


 Basophils
< 1%


 Eosinophils
< 1%


 Lymphocytes
80%


 Monocytes
11%


Platelet count
220,000/mm3



Which of the following actions by the physician is most appropriate?

choices.text: Test for EBV, HIV, and CMV infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug of the thionamide class. Like other drugs in this class, it can cause agranulocytosis. If a patient develops agranulocytosis while taking a thionamide drug, the use of another drug of the same class is contraindicated because of the high risk of cross-reactivity.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with agranulocytosis, bone marrow biopsy is useful for determining bone marrow disorders and malignancies as the underlying cause. Because bone marrow disorders (e.g., aplastic anemia) typically affect all cell lines, it is unlikely in this patient. The majority of cases of agranulocytosis are of a different etiology that can be determined without performing invasive tests.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral infection with EBV, HIV, or CMV could explain this patient's fever, malaise, and sore throat. Furthermore, infection with these viruses can suppress hematopoiesis, resulting in pancytopenia, which is defined as a decrease in the number of all cell lines in the blood (i.e., erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets). This patient, however, has isolated severe neutropenia (agranulocytosis), which is not typically caused by those viruses.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of oral aminopenicillin is the treatment of choice for patients with acute GAS tonsillitis. While this patient's findings (fever, malaise, dysphagia) are suggestive of acute tonsillitis, the absence of tonsillar exudate makes it unlikely. More importantly, this patient's laboratory tests confirm that she has agranulocytosis. She is at high risk of developing a severe, systemic infection. Oral antibiotics would not be sufficient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient recently began taking methimazole, an antithyroid drug, which is associated with a risk of agranulocytosis that usually occurs within the first 3 months of treatment. In patients with laboratory evidence of drug-induced neutropenia, the offending drug should be discontinued immediately, regardless of whether the patient is symptomatic. This patient has signs of active infection (fever, malaise, chills) in association with agranulocytosis, which should be considered a medical emergency requiring immediate discontinuation of the drug.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of active infection (fever, malaise), and the laboratory tests show severe neutropenia (agranulocytosis). This should be considered a medical emergency and requires immediate management of the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of palpitations, diaphoresis, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. Her pulse is 101/min and blood pressure is 141/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a fine tremor when the fingers are outstretched. After confirmation of the diagnosis, treatment is begun with an antithyroid medication. The physician emphasizes the need for adequate contraception because of the increased risk of severe fetal malformations associated with the use of this medication, which is why its use is discouraged in the first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Decreased iodide uptake by follicular cells
Inhibition of peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Various drugs can suppress thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) release, including corticosteroids, dopamine agonists, somatostatin analogs, and retinoids. However, none of the drugs that suppress TSH release would be prescribed for the management of hyperthyroidism. This patient was prescribed a thioamide, a class of drugs that does not act via suppression of TSH release.

B) INCORRECT:

Both lithium and iodide solutions (e.g., potassium iodide) inhibit thyroid hormone release. Lithium should be avoided during the first trimester of pregnancy because of the associated risk of fetal malformations (e.g., Ebstein anomaly). However, lithium is not routinely used in the treatment of thyroid disorders; therefore, it is unlikely that it was administered in this patient. Iodide solutions act rapidly to inhibit the release of thyroid hormones and are commonly used as adjunctive agents in the treatment of thyroid storm and severe thyrotoxicosis. However, they are neither the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism nor are they associated with severe fetal malformations. This patient was prescribed a thioamide, a class of drugs that does not act via inhibition of thyroid hormone release.

C) INCORRECT:

The uptake of iodide by follicular cells via the sodium-iodine symporter is competitively inhibited by perchlorate. Perchlorate has historically been used for the treatment of hyperthyroidism and prevention of iodine-induced hyperthyroidism (e.g., due to a contrast angiography), but the drug is no longer available in the United States and has largely been replaced by antithyroid drugs with fewer adverse effects. This patient was prescribed a thioamide, a class of drugs that does not act via inhibition of iodide uptake.

D) CORRECT:

Methimazole is a thioamide that interferes with the production of T3 and T4. It inhibits thyroid peroxidase and thus the oxidation of iodide. Because methimazole has a rapid onset of action and fewer side effects than other thioamides, it is generally the drug of choice for the treatment of hyperthyroidism. However, methimazole readily crosses the placental barrier and has been shown to cause fetal harm, including malformations such as aplasia cutis congenita, choanal atresia, and omphalocele.

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred antithyroid agent during the first trimester. PTU should then be switched to methimazole in the second trimester for the rest of pregnancy to avoid the risk of PTU-induced hepatotoxicity.
Image Description:

Left side: effect of drugs on the thyroid gland.
- Thionamides inhibit thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which blocks thyroid hormone synthesis.
- Lithium inhibits the release of thyroid hormones and may be used off-label in a thyroid storm.
- Perchlorate inhibits the sodium-iodine cotransporter in the membrane, which blocks iodide uptake in the thyroid gland.

Right side: drug effects in the periphery. A number of drugs inhibit the enzyme deiodinase, which blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to the active form T3.

E) INCORRECT:

Circulating thyroid hormones are inactivated by deiodinase 3, which converts T4 to reverse T3 (inactive form). There is no known drug with this mechanism of action.

F) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 is a mechanism of action of propylthiouracil (PTU). Although recent studies suggest that PTU is associated with an increased incidence of mild birth defects, current guidelines still recommend its use during the first trimester of pregnancy in women with a high risk of thyrotoxicosis. This patient was given a different antithyroid drug that should be avoided during the first trimester. Beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) also inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Although prolonged use of beta blockers during pregnancy can restrict fetal growth and cause fetal hypoglycemia, severe fetal malformations would not be expected.
questions.hint: The appropriate antithyroid pharmacotherapy is a drug of the thioamide class.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by a nurse 30 minutes after receiving scheduled radiation therapy for papillary thyroid cancer. After the radioisotope was ingested, the physician realized that a much larger fixed dose was given instead of the appropriate dose based on radiation dosimetry. Administration of which of the following is most likely to prevent complications from this exposure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amifostine acts as an oxygen-free radical scavenger and is used to prevent nephrotoxic side effects in patients receiving chemotherapy with platinum-based, alkylating agents (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin, and oxaliplatin). Amifostine can prevent salivary gland damage in the case of head and neck radiation or radioiodine therapy. However, it cannot protect the thyroid gland against radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil, an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid peroxidase and the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, is indicated in the treatment of hyperthyroidism and is the drug of choice in thyroid storm. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

C) INCORRECT:

Mercaptoethanesulfonate (MESNA) potentially inactivates the toxic metabolite acrolein and is therefore used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis in patients undergoing chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

D) CORRECT:

Potassium iodide should be administered immediately to prevent complications of high-dose radioiodine therapy (I131). In the case of excess exposure to radioactive iodine (e.g., in patients undergoing radioactive iodine ablation or after a nuclear accident), potassium iodide is used to decrease radioactive iodine uptake by the thyroid gland, which decreases the risk of radiation thyroiditis and radiation-induced thyroid cancer. When administered immediately after radioactive iodine overdose, nonradioactive iodine in potassium iodide competes with radioactive I131 and prevents uptake into the thyroid gland. Potassium iodide also inhibits the release of thyroid hormone by preventing the proteolytic cleavage of T3 and T4 from thyroglobulin. Therefore, it can be used as an adjunct therapy in hyperthyroidism and thyroid storm, as well as a pretreatment before thyroid surgery.
Image Description:

Left side: effect of drugs on the thyroid gland.
- Thionamides inhibit thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which blocks thyroid hormone synthesis.
- Lithium inhibits the release of thyroid hormones and may be used off-label in a thyroid storm.
- Perchlorate inhibits the sodium-iodine cotransporter in the membrane, which blocks iodide uptake in the thyroid gland.

Right side: drug effects in the periphery. A number of drugs inhibit the enzyme deiodinase, which blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to the active form T3.

E) INCORRECT:

Methimazole, an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid peroxidase and decreases thyroid hormone synthesis, is indicated in the treatment of hyperthyroidism and thyroid storm. Methimazole can be used prior to the administration of radioactive iodine therapy in patients with Graves disease to control the initial hyperthyroid phase. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

F) INCORRECT:

Dexrazoxane, an iron-chelating agent, is used to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline-based chemotherapeutic agents such as doxorubicin and daunorubicin. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.
questions.hint: High-dose radioiodine (I131) is used as adjunct therapy in the case of differentiated thyroid cancer (e.g., papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer). The drug that is used to treat an acute overdose of radioiodine is also used to treat thyroid storm because it temporarily decreases the activity of thyroid peroxidase (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman reports a 2-day history of progressive throat pain, fever, and chills. She has a history of hypertriglyceridemia, Graves disease, osteoarthritis, and depression. Her supplements and medications include fish oil, methimazole, acetaminophen, a lidocaine patch, and mirtazapine.
On physical examination, she has a temperature of 38.3°C and a heart rate of 102 beats per minute. Her pharynx is erythematous with some tonsillar exudates. The thyroid gland is enlarged, without tenderness, nodules, or bruit.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this case?

choices.text: Measurement of the thyroid-stimulating hormone level
Complete blood count with a differential leukocyte count

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no indication for intravenous dexamethasone in this setting.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography is unlikely to be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the thyroid-stimulating hormone level is not helpful in this setting, because thyroid dysfunction does not cause pharyngitis.

D) INCORRECT:

CT is unlikely to be helpful.

E) CORRECT:

Antithyroid agents, such as methimazole and propylthiouracil, can cause bone marrow suppression, most commonly agranulocytosis (an absolute neutrophil count < 500 per mm3). Agranulocytosis is seen in less than 0.5% of patients but should be distinguished from the more common occurrence of mild granulocytopenia (an absolute neutrophil count < 1500 per mm3) associated with uncontrolled Graves disease. Risk factors for agranulocytosis include higher doses of medication, more recent treatment initiation, and older age. Agranulocytosis often manifests with sore throat and fever; therefore, it must be ruled out in patients presenting with these symptoms. A complete blood count with a differential leukocyte count is recommended. Antithyroid medication should be held until the results are available. Agranulocytosis is treated with hospitalization and supportive therapy involving broad-spectrum antibiotics and, although of unproven benefit, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor.

Key learning point: The main hematologic side effect of antithyroid agents is agranulocytosis.
